description:
Podarcis cretensis, commonly known as the Cretan wall lizard, is a species of lizard endemic to the island of Crete in Greece. It belongs to the family Lacertidae, a group of small to medium-sized lizards found predominantly in Europe, Asia, and Africa.

The Cretan wall lizard is a slender, agile lizard with a snout-vent length typically ranging from 50 to 70 millimeters. Its coloration is variable, often featuring shades of brown, gray, or green, with darker bands or patterns along the body. The species is adapted to the rocky, Mediterranean habitats of Crete, where it can be found basking on walls, cliffs, and other sun-exposed surfaces.

Podarcis cretensis is an oviparous species, meaning it reproduces by laying eggs. The females typically lay a clutch of 2 to 6 eggs during the spring or early summer months. The hatchlings emerge after an incubation period of approximately 6 to 8 weeks, depending on environmental conditions.

This lizard species plays an important role in the local ecosystem, serving as a prey item for various predators, such as birds and snakes, while also contributing to the control of invertebrate populations through its insectivorous diet.

The Cretan wall lizard is considered a species of least concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), as it has a widespread distribution and is not currently facing significant threats to its population.
